Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Communication, Perturbation, and Early Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Young infants typically form lasting, emotional attachments to their caregivers. The strength and type of these attachments are related to emotional well-being and cognitive development. This project will explore how face-to-face interactions between infants and adults contribute to this important aspect of child development.

During early interactions, infants and parents form expectations about one another. Will a smile be answered with a bigger smile, for example, or with no smile at all? If the parent is asked to stop interacting and just look at her infant, will the infant smile or vocalize in an attempt to repair the interaction? Do these early patterns of interaction predict the infant's later security of attachment--their ability to be comforted after a brief separation from the parent? To answer these questions, seventy-five infants and their mothers will participate in a standard "Face-To-Face/Still-Face"
procedure at four months. Their security of attachment will then be assessed at
12 months.

It is difficult to measure early interactive behavior-and human behavior more generally-objectively and efficiently. To address this challenge, the project's interdisciplinary team of psychological and computer scientists will implement automated, quantitative measurements of behavior in the Face-To-Face/Still-Face procedure. Automated facial image analysis and pattern recognition approaches will be used to produce objective, continuous measurements of infant and mother facial expression, head motion, gaze direction, and vocalizations. Precise measurement of this multimodal suite of infant and mother behaviors will be used to tackle a fundamental scientific problem: Modeling the structure of early interaction and its relation to later development.

This is a promising approach to understanding threats to typical development and learning associated with risk factors such as maternal depression and disorders such as autism. To maximize the project's impact, the team will make a database of audiovisual recordings, automated measurements, and pattern recognition and modeling software available to other scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Face-to-face interaction with parents or other caregivers is critical to infants’ social and emotional development. Face-to-face interaction is a context for early socialization experience and contributes to infants’ developing sense of identity and expectations of other people.  Individual differences in patterns of parent-infant interaction influence the development of security of infant attachment and social competence. Until recently, our understanding of face-to-face interaction has been hampered by reliance on subjective measures.  It has not been possible to objectively measure intra- and interpersonal social and emotional behavior and model their dynamics over time. To address this challenge, our interdisciplinary team of psychologists and computer scientists, with expertise in human behavior, computer vision, and machine learning, implemented automated, quantitative measurements of interactive behavior in the Still-Face (SF) paradigm.

The SF paradigm consists of three contiguous episodes.  Parent and infant play as they would normally for 2 minutes (Play). The parent then becomes unresponsive for 2 minutes (Still Face) that is followed by 2 minutes of normal interaction (Reunion).  The SF paradigm is a well-validated procedure for assessing infants’ and parents’ ability to regulate stress, social engagement, and response to age-appropriate challenges.  

We addressed several goals related to parent-infant face-to-face interaction. One, we developed and implemented automatic, objective measures of parent and infant communication  (De la Torre et al., 2015; Zaker et al., 2014). The SF paradigm consists of three contiguous episodes: 2 min of mother-infant play,  2 min in which the mother remains seated en face but is unresponsive, and 2 min in which she  attempts to re-engage her infant in normal face-to-face play. Observational methods included automatic face detection, facial feature tracking, tracking of head orientation, and detection of discrete facial expressions and their intensity.  Two, we used time-series approaches appropriate to the time-varying dynamics of parent-infant interaction (Chow et al., in press; Messinger et al., 2014).  We made discoveries about the “packaging” of infant expression and its coordination with the parent. And three, we made our methods available for other researchers and clinicians to use in their research and practice.

We used objective methods to investigate mother-infant interaction. We tested Darwin’s hypothesis that eye constriction and mouth opening are associated with both intense positive and negative emotion (Mattson et al., 2013).  This finding suggests greater parsimony in emotion expression than previously recognized.  In other work, we tested the hypothesis that mother-infant communication is co-constructed and the direction of influence varies over time.  These findings suggest that mismatches are frequent and that mothers’ and infants’ ability to repair these mismatches is an important individual difference.

To promote research in infant social development, we have made available for public use software for automatic analysis of facial expression (http://www.humansensing.cs.cmu.edu/intraface/) and video recordings of mother-infant interactions toegher with computer tracking of each video frame along with other measures (https://nyu.databrary.org/).
